definitions.definition: giving or willing to give freely; given freely
definitions.sensetop: generous with somethinggenerous to somebodygenerous in somethinggenerous in doing somethingit is generous of somebodyit is generous of somebody to do something

examples.text: The gallery was named after its most generous benefactor.
You've been incredibly generous with your time.
He was generous to his friends and family.
She was generous in her praise for her co-stars.
They were very generous in giving help
Thank you for your donation. It was very generous of you.
It was extremely generous of him to offer to pay for us both.
examples.contextForm: it is generous of somebody to do something

examples.text: They were very generous with the food!
She's quite generous with her praise.
They have been extremely generous to the church.
He's a kind and generous man.
The director thanked the chairman for his generous gift.
The car has a generous amount of space.
The review panel criticized the payments as overly generous.

definitions.definition: kind in the way you treat people; willing to see what is good about somebody/something

examples.text: He wrote a very generous assessment of my work.
Her generous spirit shone through in everything she did.

wordOrigin: late 16th cent.: via Old French from Latin generosus ‘noble, magnanimous’, from genus, gener- ‘stock, race’. The original sense was ‘of noble birth’, hence ‘characteristic of noble birth, courageous, magnanimous, not mean’ (a sense already present in Latin).
